overview_of_class:
Overview of state-of-the-art work in building computational models of human language comprehension, acquisition, and production. Students will learn about the many uses of instantiated computational models in
these areas of research and will learn how to interpret and evaluate the claims made by these models. The course will be based around primary papers from the recent literature.
name: Topics in Linguistics
subject: LING

overview_of_class: We study two broad categories of experimental research relevant to meaning in natural language: (i) research testing truth-conditional theories ("experimental semantics"), and (ii) research exploring the relationship between meaning and non-linguistic cognition ("psychosemantics"). These two categories of research have different scope, limits, and methods. This course develops an understanding of the state of contemporary experimental research on meaning through readings, lecture, and discussion. Specific topics to be covered might include the mass/count distinction, plurality, event semantics, quantifiers, numerals, vagueness, gradability, and presupposition.
name: Topics in Linguistics
subject: LING
